title: Trump blasts GM for Mexican-made Chevy Cruze
content:
President-elect Donald Trump took aim at General Motors ( GM ) for making a version of the Chevrolet Cruze in Mexico and selling it in the U.S. , further signaling the likelihood of a showdown with the auto industry over free-trade policies .
`` Make in U.S.A.or pay big border tax ! '' Trump said on Twitter .
GM acknowledged that `` a small number '' of the recently launched Cruze hatchback are made in Mexico and sold in the U.S .
Cruze sedans sold in the U.S. are made exclusively at GM 's sprawling factory in Lordstown , Ohio . A plant in Ramos , Mexico , makes the Cruze sedan for foreign markets .
Trump slammed GM on Twitter for `` sending Mexican-made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border . ''
Despite the tweet , GM 's stock was up 1.8 % in early trading Tuesday .
Trump 's criticism of GM comes after he has repeatedly assailed the North American Free Trade Agreement for speeding the transfer of U.S. automotive production to Mexico . Trump , a noted fan of GM 's Cadillac brand , had previously spared the automaker from criticism , instead taking aim at Ford Motor for manufacturing vehicles in Mexico .
A month ago GM CEO Mary Barra agreed to join a panel of CEOs who will advise Trump on economic policy .
The U.S. auto industry has defended NAFTA as critical to its business model , but Trump has described the deal as venomous to American jobs . He has proposed a 35 % tariff on Mexican-made goods imported to the U.S .
In that respect he is aligned with the United Auto Workers union , which has called for Washington to crater NAFTA , endorsed the proposed tariff and signaled a willingness to work with Trump to make it happen .
UAW wants to join Trump in effort to crush NAFTA
`` I ’ m prepared to sit down and talk to him about trade . NAFTA is a problem , '' UAW President Dennis Williams told reporters after Trump 's election . `` I think his position on trade is right on . ''
GM in November announced plans to cut the third shift at the sprawling Lordstown factory on Jan. 23 , displacing more than 1,200 hourly workers .
content_original:
Nathan Bomey

USA TODAY

President-elect Donald Trump took aim at General Motors (GM) for making a version of the Chevrolet Cruze in Mexico and selling it in the U.S., further signaling the likelihood of a showdown with the auto industry over free-trade policies.

"Make in U.S.A.or pay big border tax!" Trump said on Twitter.

GM acknowledged that "a small number" of the recently launched Cruze hatchback are made in Mexico and sold in the U.S.

Cruze sedans sold in the U.S. are made exclusively at GM's sprawling factory in Lordstown, Ohio. A plant in Ramos, Mexico, makes the Cruze sedan for foreign markets.

Trump slammed GM on Twitter for "sending Mexican-made model of Chevy Cruze to U.S. car dealers-tax free across border."

Despite the tweet, GM's stock was up 1.8% in early trading Tuesday.

Trump's criticism of GM comes after he has repeatedly assailed the North American Free Trade Agreement for speeding the transfer of U.S. automotive production to Mexico. Trump, a noted fan of GM's Cadillac brand, had previously spared the automaker from criticism, instead taking aim at Ford Motor for manufacturing vehicles in Mexico.

A month ago GM CEO Mary Barra agreed to join a panel of CEOs who will advise Trump on economic policy.

The U.S. auto industry has defended NAFTA as critical to its business model, but Trump has described the deal as venomous to American jobs. He has proposed a 35% tariff on Mexican-made goods imported to the U.S.

In that respect he is aligned with the United Auto Workers union, which has called for Washington to crater NAFTA, endorsed the proposed tariff and signaled a willingness to work with Trump to make it happen.

UAW wants to join Trump in effort to crush NAFTA

"I’m prepared to sit down and talk to him about trade. NAFTA is a problem," UAW President Dennis Williams told reporters after Trump's election. "I think his position on trade is right on."

GM in November announced plans to cut the third shift at the sprawling Lordstown factory on Jan. 23, displacing more than 1,200 hourly workers.
